Award.AwardTitle: Fully three-dimensional numerical models for along-axis variations in magmatic and tectonic processes at slow-spreading mid-ocean ridges
Award.AbstractNarration:
The recent observations of oceanic core complexes (OCCs) are intriguing. OCCs are formed when faults keep slipping and eventually exhume lower crust and mantle rocks onto the seafloor. OCCs not only provide a glimpse into Earth's mantle by uncovering deep-seated rocks, but they commonly have hydrothermal vents associated with them which host large ecosystems. When first discovered, OCCs were assumed to form primarily near the ends of slow-spreading mid-ocean ridge segments where magma supply is low. However, they also have been found at locations far from spreading segment ends. Moreover, in some place the formation of OCCs alternates with normal seafloor spreading which produces short-lived faults. It is unclear what controls the alternating faulting styles. This project will produce a three-dimensional mechanical model to understand the controls on the formation of OCCs at mid-ocean ridges. The overarching goal is to understand the role of faulting in the formation and evolution of the ocean basins. The project will recruit undergraduate students to participate in the research with a priority on identifying participants from groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. Movies will be generated explaining the model and model results and will be used in graduate courses and adapted for use in K-12 schools.

Diking frequencies and faulting styles are highly variable at slow-spreading mid-ocean ridges and correlated with each other to some degree. However, our understanding of the mechanism behind the correlation and other factors controlling faulting styles is still incomplete. The objectives of this project are to establish the mechanism that determines faulting styles in response to spatially and temporally varying diking frequencies at slow-spreading ridges and to quantify the sensitivity of the mechanism to fault-lubricating processes and magma extrusion and under-plating at spreading centers. The project proposes to develop a three-dimensional (3D) modeling approach by extending an existing two-dimensional (2D) method that has been successful in explaining the main morphological and structural features in across-axis sections of mid-ocean ridges in terms of diking frequencies. The fully 3D numerical models incorporate the along-axis mechanical loading arising from variability in diking and faulting. Furthermore, the modeling method will consider other important factors affecting faulting styles such as lubrication effects of frictionally weak minerals forming on fault surfaces. Four suites of numerical experiments will be conducted in the order of increasing complexity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
New observations of oceanic core complexes (OCCs), where detachment faults (i.e., large-offset low-angle normal faults) exhume lower crust and mantle rocks onto the seafloor, are posing new questions about how ocean floors form. For instance, OCCs were assumed to form preferably near the magma-poor tips of a ridge segment but are now found even at locations far from segment ends, which is anomalous in the light of existing models for faulting at mid-ocean ridges. Some OCCs alternate with abyssal hills along the ridge axis but it is unclear whether the alternating faulting styles mean that an undulating detachment fault is locally buried under extrusives or that a detachment is truncated by accommodation zones. In a broader perspective, the system of spreading centers is the main place where magma exits the mantle and fluids and volatiles are exchanged with the hydrosphere and atmosphere. Also, some large hydrothermal systems are associated with OCCs. Because of this interrelated nature of processes occurring at mid-ocean ridges, the findings from this project have potential to illuminate on the role of faulting in the formation and evolution of ocean basins as well as in the development of deep ecosystems that is tightly coupled to hydrothermal circulation in the crust. This project newly established that axially-variable magmatic accretion controls faulting pattern transition along slow-spreading ridge axis. The three-dimensional numerical models created in this project show that faulting at slow-spreading ridges can occur in the  *transitional mode*, in which a detachment and a short-lived normal fault form and stay active simultaneously within a 20 km-long ridge segment. Those two distinctive faulting modes have respective domains separated by a transfer fault. The transitional mode of faulting appears when faults weaken at a slow rate and diking rate is moderate; when faults weaken fast and diking rate is low, a detachment, as long as the ridge segment itself (> 15 km) and continuous, can form creating a segment-wide oceanic core complex.

Another significant finding out of this project is that serpentinization is the most important weakening mechanism for the formation of corrugated surface at ultraslow-spreading ridges. Mid-ocean ridges are said to be ultraslow when their spreading speed is smaller than 1 cm/yr. Exceptionally slow spreading makes the lithosphere at spreading center much thicker than the counterpart of faster-spreading ridges and the thick axial lithosphere is the origin of many distinctive characteristics of the ultraslow-spreading ridge systems. Accumulating new observations on the corrugated surfaces at Southwest Indian Ridge (SWIR), one of the ultraslow-spreading ridges, compel us to test whether the existing models for this defining surface feature of an OCC would be extended to ultraslow ridges because the models are mostly based on the observations on faster-spreading ridges. This project took the two-dimensional numerical modeling approach to assessing individually the two main weakening mechanisms considered to be needed for the formation of corrugated surface: Serpentinization of mantle rock and talc formation in lower crust. They verified that, without serpentinization, detachment faulting necessary for exposing corrugated surfaces does not occur for all the tested ratios of magmatic accretion rate in the brittle lithosphere to total plate spreading rate. Serpentinization and low magmatic accretion rates in the upper crust are dominantly important for the formation of corrugated surface. The talc-forming reaction at the interface between gabbro and mantle rocks has only secondary impact. It helps a corrugated surface live longer but cannot initiate the formation without serpentinization.

The project made broader impacts by providing various training opportunities for the next-generation earth scientists and by disseminating the research outcomes to relevant communities and beyond. Supporting collaboration between the research groups at the University of Memphis and Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, the project helped the involved graduate students understand the importance of knowledge dissemination and obtain hands-on experience with communication and network building. With research progress boosted by this interaction, a graduate student could present preliminary results from his research at a professional conference only after several months since he started working on the project. The PI leveraged the undergraduate research program at the University of Memphis to recruit an undergraduate research intern; and provided her with experiences with research in computational geodynamics. The significant results, described above, either have been published in a peer-reviewed journal or are going to be submitted for publication. The associated data and codes have been posted on the project web site and on an open data repository so that they are available to general public and to other researchers who want to reproduce and build upon this project. The PI gave several public lecture on the project?s research topics as well as on other important facts about mid-ocean ridge systems for undergraduate and graduate students at US and South Korean institutions.
